Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 37, Heaven of YÄma, Section 23
At that time, the king of the YÄma Heaven told the heavenly multitudes:
Why do you not now enjoy yourselves in the gardens, forests, flower ponds, and on the peaks of mountains adorned with innumerable jewels, singing, dancing, and laughing?
The heavenly king thus observes the heavenly multitudes to see if they are becoming disgusted or not.
When the heavenly multitudes heard what the king of the YÄma Heaven said, they addressed the heavenly king, saying:
Where in the gardens, forests, and peaks of the seven-jeweled mountains can there be a place of joy?
I see innumerable sufferings and afflictions of birth and death, with innumerable distinctions, that are unbearable.
With my own eyes, I see that all desires are impermanent, and in the end they all lead to suffering.
These desires are impermanent and do not last. They will soon decay and be destroyed, without solidity or joy.
At that time, the king of the YÄma Heaven, having heard the heavenly multitudes speak, said to them:
'You should now know!
All desires and pleasures will eventually lead to suffering.'
At that time, the heavenly multitudes said to the heavenly king:
'We now understand that desires are great suffering.'
At that time, the king of the YÄma Heaven said to the heavenly multitudes:

'I can proclaim the immeasurable sufferings of all birth and death. Now I will briefly explain a little to you, so that for billions and trillions of kalpas you will not be indulgent again, but will always practice the two kinds of good ways of humans and gods.
If you cut off indulgence, that is wisdom.
If the conditions for indulgence come, you should immediately distance yourself from them.
If you are not made to serve indulgence, then you will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.'
He further said to the heavenly multitudes:
'Now I will explain to you the three evil destinies and the two kinds of good destinies.
The two good destinies are that of gods and humans.
The three evil destinies refer to the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Such are the sufferings of the five destinies with great power. I can explain them, but it is impossible to elaborate. I will now briefly explain.
In brief, there are sixteen sufferings among gods and humans.
What are the sixteen?
Among gods and humans, the good destinies are included.
First, the suffering of the intermediate state;
Second, the suffering of dwelling in the womb;
Third, the suffering of leaving the womb;
Fourth, the suffering of seeking food;
Fifth, the suffering of encountering what is disliked;
Sixth, the suffering of separation from what is loved;
Seventh, the suffering of cold, heat, and so forth;
Eighth, the suffering of illness;
Ninth, the suffering of being a servant to others;
Tenth, the suffering of pursuing and working;
Eleventh, the suffering of associating with bad friends;
Twelfth, the suffering of the distress of wives, children, and relatives;
Thirteenth, the suffering of hunger and thirst;
Fourteenth, the suffering of being slighted by others;
Fifteenth, the suffering of old age;
Sixteenth, the suffering of death.
These sixteen are the great sufferings among humans. In the human world, until the end of life, and other sufferings, in the cycle of birth and death, are unbearable.
In conditioned things, there is no little happiness. All are impermanent, all are exhausted, all are decaying.
When first born in the intermediate state, consciousness is like a fragrance. What are the sufferings?
Blown by the wind of karma, not seen by the physical eye, seen by the heavenly eye, but unobstructed.
If born among humans, born in a family of good social standing, there are low, middle, and high.
Those who wish to be born through the fruits of giving, keeping precepts, and wisdom, this consciousness, the fragrance in the intermediate state, also obtains such food.
If wishing to be born in a poor family, the food eaten is coarse and rough, the color, smell, taste, and touch are all coarse and evil, the body is small and inferior.
Because of little giving, one does not obtain superior rewards.
This is called being born among humans, the suffering of the first intermediate state.
Next, the second suffering:

If born in the womb, due to the causes and conditions of karma and afflictions, one dwells in a poor family. The mother eats coarse, rough, bitter, and sour food. In the membrane sheath, the little food flavor enters her navel, causing the child in the womb to have a weak body and bad complexion, with little energy.
Because the mother is tired, the child in the womb experiences great suffering. It turns to the two sides and runs away in pain.
The mother eats cold or hot food, and it suffers pain. It has no strength and no savior, unable to cry out.
Submerged in feces and urine, it experiences immeasurable suffering.
This is the second great suffering for humans in the good realms, let alone in the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Next, the third suffering:
When born from the womb, the womb's confinement is like being squeezed in an oil press. When an infant emerges from the womb, the pain of falling is also like that. This is great suffering.
Furthermore, when first born, the body is soft like a lump of fresh butter, also like a banana plant, and also like a ripe fruit.
A midwife attends the birth and holds it with her hands.
Her hands are rough, cracked, and split, with long sharp fingernails, and her face is ugly.
When she holds it with her hands, it is like being burned by fire or cut by a knife.
In this way, the infant's body is delicate and soft, and when the midwife touches it, it experiences great pain.
If it gets new clothes, they are coarse, rough, and heavy.
Or if it gets old clothes, they are patched, torn, with holes and gaps, narrow, thin, and it sleeps on a grass mat.
When cold, it is very cold and experiences great cold suffering;
when hot, it is very hot, like being burned by fire.
Because of the impurity of their original giving, they experience this suffering.
After coming out of the womb, they experience great suffering.
Furthermore, due to the causes and conditions of impure giving, they cause their mothers to have little milk and to eat bitter and astringent things.
Because the mother's food is inferior, her milk is then little, or because the mother's food is coarse and bad, it causes her milk to be little.
She is emaciated, ugly, and her body is only sinews, skin, and bones.

Because of hunger, thirst, and illness, her body has no strength. If she has nothing to eat, she begs from others, is despised by people, and obtains little food and drink with little color, smell, and taste.
She relies on others for food, and with difficulty sustains her life. In this way, lacking food causes suffering for the body.
Because of the unwholesome giving she originally practiced, until the end of her life, she is always not satisfied.
Because of lacking food, she always experiences suffering.
Furthermore, the fourth suffering is:

They suffer from hunger and thirst, and are tormented by hunger and thirst. They may become thieves and commit all kinds of evil deeds, or do things that are not beneficial. They may become brave and strong, but end up losing their lives or suffering death.
The heaviest of all sufferings is hunger and thirst.'
At that time, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana spoke in verse to the heavenly multitudes, saying:
The great suffering of birth and death is not equal to hunger and thirst.
Because of the suffering of hunger, sentient beings commit all kinds of unwholesome deeds.
The fire that arises from one's own body is called the suffering of hunger and thirst.
Hunger and thirst burn three places, like the fire at the end of an eon burning a forest.
The great flaming fire in the world cannot reach the next world,
But the fire of hunger and thirst is difficult to extinguish, reaching hundreds of thousands of eons.
Foolish people create unwholesomeness and walk on treacherous and evil paths,
All for the sake of food and drink. The wise say this.
Hunger and thirst have great power, surpassing a great raging fire,
In all the three realms, it is due to the cause of food that they turn.
If in the human world there are various kinds of wealth and goods,
All are accomplished due to food, turning the ocean of the three existences.
' Thus, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana spoke to the gods, saying:
'Moreover, heavenly multitudes, there is a fifth suffering in the human world, namely the six kinds of suffering of encountering enemies and those one detests.
What are the six?
Namely, the eyes see enemies and so forth, the mind is not delighted, and the mind does not pity them.
Seeing their bodily appearance, the mind is disturbed, and fear arises in the mind and mental factors, giving rise to what is not beneficial.
In the mind and mental factors, suffering and distress arise.
Among all evils, the first and foremost evil is seeing the appearance of enemies and bad friends.
' Moreover, the second suffering of encountering enemies and those one detests:
If one hears a sound that is not beneficial, not loved, and not in accord with one's mind, and becomes agitated, this is the suffering of being with what is disliked.
The first bad sound is the sound of hearing and grasping incorrect teachings.
Because of detesting and hating the sound, when the body perishes and life ends, one falls into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animal realms.

If one hears an unloved and unbeneficial sound, and upon hearing it gives rise to an evil mind and agitation, not loving or enjoying it, and the mind has no compassion, this is the suffering of being united with what is unloved and disliked among humans.

Next, the third suffering of being united with what is unloved and disliked is when the nose smells a fragrance that is unloved and not enjoyed, and the mind does not follow along. Smelling it, the mind becomes agitated and may give rise to deep suffering.
This is a great evil, being united with what is unloved.
The celestial sons and so forth, this is being united with what is unloved among humans.

If a person is foolish and lacks wisdom, whether walking or standing, their mind gives rise to greed and attachment, and they are arrogant and disrespectful. If someone offers incense to the Dharma and Sangha, that person will then smell it with a lustful mind. When their body perishes and their life ends, they will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animal realms.
In this way, evil people, due to their bodies, because of greed for the body, their body and mind are impure. When their body perishes and their life ends, they fall into the hells.
All you heavenly beings!
This is the suffering of being forced to associate with those one dislikes among humans.
Furthermore, the fourth suffering of being forced to associate with those one dislikes is as follows: In the world, foolish and evil people commit evil deeds because of craving for tastes.
Because of their evil deeds, when their body perishes and their life ends, they fall into the hells.
If they are not monks but appear as monks, inwardly rotten like the sound of a flute.
Whether in a monastery or a layperson's house, they are not true monks but wear the robes of monks, always greedy for delicious food, bound by craving for tastes.
For these reasons, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into hell.
There are also lazy bhiká¹£us who abandon the taste of meditation and travel around everywhere for the sake of delicious food, their minds always delighting in food.
Because of their laziness, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into hell.
All you celestial sons!
This is called the suffering of not loving to gather in the human realm, which arises due to attachment to flavors.
Furthermore, celestial sons!

In the human realm, the fifth suffering of not loving to gather refers to the bodily touch that binds the mind, improper thoughts, non-dharmic conduct that does not accord with the Dharma, and improper mental focus.
Such evil people, bound by evil objects, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into hell.
All you celestial sons!
This is called the suffering of not loving to gather in the human realm.
Furthermore, celestial beings!
In the human realm, the sixth suffering of not loving to gather refers to

Namely, there are people whose minds are restless and cannot be still, whose minds are not correct, who are often distracted, who always think of evil karma, who do not enjoy good dharmas, who enjoy unwholesome dharmas and unprofitable matters.
For this reason, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil paths and are born in hells.
All you celestial beings!

This is the unpleasant gathering and association that gives rise to suffering and distress in the human realm, as well as various other immeasurable sufferings that are fully experienced in the human realm.

There are also three kinds of suffering of encountering enemies and those one dislikes, namely: being close to enemies, fearing they will harm one's life, like a thorn in the eye, always not being in accord.
This is the first suffering of encountering enemies and those one dislikes.
Next, the second suffering of encountering enemies and those one dislikes:
Engaging in the same activities as bad friends is called the second suffering of encountering enemies and those one dislikes.
Next, the third suffering of encountering enemies and those one dislikes:
harboring anger within, they find an opportunity to harm, this is called the third suffering of being with what is not loved and being separated from what is loved.
All you celestial sons!
This is the immeasurable suffering in the human realm.'
At that time, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana further spoke for the sake of the celestial beings' attainment of detachment, saying:
'The sixth great suffering among humans is called the suffering of separation from what is loved.

Benefiting both oneself and others is called love. The great suffering of separation from good friends is like falling into a knife or fire, burning one's body and mind and experiencing great suffering and distress. This is called the suffering of separation from what is loved.'
The YÄma Heaven King expounded this Dharma for the sake of the celestial beings.
At that time, the YÄma Heaven King further spoke for the celestial beings, saying:
'The seventh great suffering among humans is called the suffering of cold and heat.
All you celestial sons!
What are the two sufferings of cold and heat among humans?
In the human realm, if one's diet is not balanced, it may be cold when it should be hot, or hot when it should be cold.
Sitting for a long time is suffering, standing for a long time is also suffering, drinking too much is suffering, and not sleeping is also suffering.
If one lies on one's right side in the dark night, sleeping for a long time is suffering, as is sleeping on one's left side. Initially pleasant, later it becomes suffering.
In the human world, because of craving for pleasure, one is deceived by pleasure and cultivates wholesome actions.
Because of being deceived by pleasure, one enters hell.
All you heavenly beings!
The pleasure in the human realm is no different from suffering.'
In this way, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana benefits the heavenly multitudes and explains the Dharma like this:
'You heavenly multitudes should not give rise to this thought, that the pleasure in the human realm should cause one to give rise to aversion.
In order to be free from birth and death, the Dharma is explained to benefit, to remove the heavenly beings' heedlessness.
Furthermore, the king of the YÄma Heaven again said to the YÄma Heaven's assembly:
'The eighth great suffering among humans is the suffering of illness.
There are immeasurable distinctions and immeasurable illnesses that arise, namely hot fevers, diarrhea, vomiting, and the four hundred and four illnesses that harm sentient beings.
There are also illnesses that harm sentient beings, such as the illnesses of worry, sorrow, and grief. These are the great sufferings among humans.'

At that time, the YÄma Heaven King Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, in order to benefit the heavenly assembly, again spoke of the ninth great suffering, causing them to be free from birth and death, and showed them the great suffering of birth and death among humans.
'Namely, being enslaved by others among humans is a great suffering.

Those who have the same path, the same birth, the same faculties, the same age, and the same strength, due to their inferior karma, are enslaved by others, unable to be free whether during the day or night, and always experience great suffering.
This is the suffering of being enslaved by others among humans.
Next, there is the suffering of being enslaved by others.
If a person has the best family lineage, diligent appearance and strength, and is fully endowed with reading, recitation, and wisdom, but due to poverty is employed by lowly people.
' At that time, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana, in order to bring benefit to the YÄma Heaven assembly, further taught the Dharma:
' Due to inferior karma, lacking the karma of giving, despised by others, suffering day and night, employed by others.

Lacking the conditions of giving, always experiencing suffering, with cracked hands and feet, poor and lacking food, dirty and tattered clothing, tormented by hunger and thirst, suffering from cold and heat.
Such immeasurable suffering is unbearable, employed day and night, without interruption.
Among humans, there are also those with inferior family lineage, appearance, and power, yet who are wealthy.

There are also those of noble lineage, with superior appearance, strength, and wisdom, who are always poor. Because of their poverty, they associate with low-class people. Deceived by their work and their minds, they experience great suffering.
Celestial sons!
This is the suffering of being employed by others among humans.
Next, there is the suffering of being employed by others.

If poor people act in accordance with the Dharma, because of their poverty they associate with those of evil conduct and unwholesome people. Because of associating with the unwholesome, they engage in evil actions together. Although they do not enjoy it, they are employed by others and create evil karma. When their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into the evil destinies and are born in the hells.
Because of being employed by others, they experience suffering in two lifetimes.
Furthermore, celestial beings!
In the human realm, they experience great suffering, namely the tenth suffering of pursuing.

They experience immeasurable suffering and hardship in pursuit of wealth, entering the great ocean, engaging in battle, engaging in business, speaking with eloquence, associating with the lowly, farming, trading, raising livestock, and traveling to distant places.
Driven by profit, they climb great mountains and cliffs, wandering everywhere, relying on others.
All such pursuits are for the sake of wealth and the adornment of clothing.
Whether poor or attached, they pursue in this way, bound by the net of desire until the end of their lives.
They may commit evil deeds or tell lies to deceive others, using light weights and small measures to cheat people;
selling alcohol, sesame, and poison;
engaging in such evil conduct and commerce.
They may destroy countries, cities, villages, military camps, and various other evil deeds.
For the sake of wives, children, food and drink, bedding and other possessions, the suffering of pursuit is immeasurable, even if one were to speak for a thousand years, it would not be exhausted.
All you sons of gods!
This is called the suffering of pursuit in the human realm.'
In this way, the king of the YÄma Heaven benefits the heavenly multitudes and causes them to become disgusted with existence. He expounds the ultimate Dharma, saying:
'All you sons of gods!
Do not give rise to a longing mind in the human realm, but should give rise to disgust. If you crave existence, you will not obtain benefit.
For this reason, I speak of all the afflictions in the human realm.
If one is born in the human realm, because of pursuit, one creates unwholesome karma. For this reason, one may fall into hell, or fall into the realm of animals or hungry ghosts.
Having already been born in the evil destinies, one experiences various sufferings.'
In this way, the king of the YÄma Heaven again spoke of the great suffering of eleven kinds in the human realm, addressing the heavenly multitudes, saying:
'The great suffering among humans is this: associating with bad friends is all unbeneficial and the cause of suffering.
Associating with bad friends, one cannot avoid evil, and creates all evil actions of body, speech, and mind.
For this reason, when the body perishes and life ends, one falls into evil paths, is born in the hells, and experiences immeasurable suffering.
In future lives, one may fall into the realms of hungry ghosts and animals, and experience immeasurable suffering.

Having observed the faults of the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals among humans, he prevents the heavenly beings from longing for human existence and speaks of the one place of nirvana and tranquility.'
Furthermore, the king of the YÄma Heaven, in order to benefit the YÄma Heaven's assembly, spoke of the suffering among humans:

'The twelfth great suffering in the human realm is the suffering of wives, children, and relatives. It refers to the various sufferings such as killing, binding, beating, hunger, thirst, and poverty of wives, children, and relatives. Because one's loved ones suffer, one also suffers. This is called suffering.
In the human realm, one obtains suffering due to the causes and conditions of wives, children, relatives, and associates. Therefore, do not delight in being born in the human realm.
All beings are destined to die. Wherever there is death, there is suffering.
The greatest suffering in birth and death is birth, old age, and death. Humans have all of these.
Celestial sons!
Knowing that such great suffering in the human realm is unbearable, do not delight in it.

With these immeasurable good, peaceful, and unsurpassed teachings of the path, he shows the heavenly beings that in the human realm there are unprofitable things, various nets of existence that cannot be compared, let alone the immeasurable hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of inconceivable great sufferings in the three evil realms, which are not comparable to those in the human realm.
When the gods are about to fall, the slightly negligent gods will say to them:
'You will be reborn in the good realms of humans.
If a person is about to die, their relatives and friends wish for them to be reborn in the good realms of the heavens.
The two good realms are still like this, let alone the great suffering experienced in the three evil realms.

Such benefits and guidance, always being diligent, the king of the YÄma Heaven expounds immeasurable kinds, immeasurable distinctions, immeasurable skillful means, and immeasurable kinds of teachings, the supreme teaching of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Having explained the suffering of wife and children, he further expounded to the YÄma Heaven's assembly:
'The thirteenth great suffering among humans is the suffering of hunger and thirst.
Due to hunger and thirst, one commits immeasurable evil.
Among all sufferings, none is like hunger and thirst. Because of hunger and thirst, one enters into many evil situations.

People of great lineage, for the sake of food and drink, join their palms, shed tears, and with a sorrowful voice, approach lowly and mean people, speaking affectionate words. All of this is due to hunger and thirst.
Fearing hunger and thirst, one disregards one's life and enters dangerous places, between sword blades and fierce elephants and enemies. All of this is due to the suffering of hunger and thirst.

One may enter the great ocean, traveling immeasurable hundreds of thousands of yojanas, through immeasurable evil places with large fish, dolphins, and whales, and great waves. One abandons one's body and life, riding on a leaky boat, which sinks in the great ocean.
All of this is due to fearing the suffering of hunger and thirst.
There are also immeasurable different kinds, which cannot be fully described.
Such sufferings are all for the sake of the mouth and stomach.

If a person is bound and taken out through the right gate, beating a bad-sounding drum, adorned with a garland of death, with a disaster flag in front, frightened and distressed, taken to the place of execution, with life remaining for a short while, although greatly suffering, hunger and thirst are not yet exceeded.
Therefore, one should with a pure and good mind, in the field of merit, with good wealth, practice giving, complete in time and place.
In the midst of the fears of birth and death, diligently cultivate and practice, with a good mind give.
In the heavens, there is little hunger, and all birth and death rely on food and drink to remove hunger and thirst. Therefore, all should practice giving.
O assembly of gods!
This is the immeasurable distinctions in the suffering of hunger and thirst among humans.
In the heavenly path, the suffering is slight and soft, covered by heavenly bliss, because of much merit and virtue, food and drink are easily obtained.
But the gods do not realize that in the desire realm, they are covered by the flames of hunger and thirst, fearing the fire of suffering.
O sons of gods!
Thus contemplate the various sufferings of birth, old age, sickness, and death among humans, and do not give rise to delight.'
In this way, the night-shining god king Moxiu Lou Tuo saw that the minds of the night-shining gods had become subdued and mostly gentle and pliable.
Having observed this, he further spoke to the gods about the sufferings in the human realm, diligently cultivating benefiting others, while benefiting oneself is easy.
Moxiu Lou Tuo, with the power of unceasing effort, for the sake of benefiting others, repeatedly proclaimed countless kinds of teachings for the assembly of night-shining gods, saying:
'The fourteenth great suffering among humans is the suffering of being despised by others, which is unbearable and has various distinctions.
There are ten kinds of suffering for the poor, despised by their clan, relatives, brothers, and the wealthy.
Due to the suffering of poverty, they rely on others for food.
They speak incoherently and untruthfully, with empty words and meaningless speech to their relatives.
Relying on others for food and clothing, being defiled by dust and dirt from others, and being despised by others.
If entering a city or on a festival day, people see and despise them.
In the human realm, there are such immeasurable despisings and great sufferings.
In the world, people have a fire without fuel residing in their hearts, namely the fire of despising. The fire of relatives, acquaintances, and siblings burns the most severely.
Due to lacking merit and virtue, one obtains these ten sufferings that burn one's body everywhere.
The great evil fears burn the dry body, and the breath rises like smoke.
All you heavenly beings!
You should be content and do not delight in the human realm. The little happiness in the human realm is greatly troubled, with decline, distress, short life, and defiled by despising.
Only in the human realm are there many despisings, not in the four paths.
In the human realm, despising is the heaviest.
Obtaining the despising of others, all parts of the body are as if poisoned.
Following the places where they originally obtained offerings, they later despise and slander them.

If a person previously always obtained good offerings, but later obtains little benefit, little time of offerings, if a good man despises and slanders in this way, it is worse than the suffering of death.
All you celestial sons!
This is the great suffering that is difficult to endure among humans.
Furthermore, the fifteenth great suffering among humans, namely the suffering of old age, I will now explain the suffering of old age among humans for you.

Old age can cause all parts of the body to become emaciated and weak, the faculties all mature, destroying youthfulness, walking with a cane, lacking strength, despised in one's dwelling, with a hunched back and crooked nose, white hair, the messenger of death, the body and mind becoming inferior.
Although not yet dead, it is like being an animal.
All you celestial sons!
This is called the suffering of old age among humans, being toyed with by name and form, and will certainly die before long.
If one sees the suffering of old age but is not afraid, one should know that such a person is mindless, like a piece of wood or stone.
Because of being mindless, even though one has a human body, it is like an animal.
All good men!
Being born in the human realm is a great suffering, because of being born, there is the suffering of old age.
Having known the suffering of old age, do not give rise to a joyful mind in the human realm.
Furthermore, the sixteenth, in the human realm there are innumerable kinds of birth. Being born is suffering. What kind of suffering is it?
It is called the suffering of death.
Having died, one is born again, the faculties of the body are destroyed, the life faculty is extinguished, and one never sees one's brothers and friends again.
After the physical body is destroyed, one goes to another place, taking one's own karmic fruits as provisions.
All sentient beings will surely return to their end. When life ends and the body is abandoned, one receives the intermediate existence. This is called death.
All beings are subject to death. If one dies but does not take rebirth, or is reborn but does not die, this is impossible!
All you celestial sons!
Do not give rise to a mind of pleasure towards the human realm!'
At that time, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana spoke in verse, saying:
In the human world, all the aggregates are suffering.
Those who are born will eventually return to death, and those who die will certainly be reborn.
If one dwells in the intermediate state of existence, one will suffer the afflictions of one's own karma,
The suffering of long nights of distant travel, this suffering cannot be described.
Drowning in feces and urine, burned by hot air,
Such is the suffering of dwelling in the womb, it cannot be fully described.
Always craving the flavors of food, the mind always hopes,
Experiencing great suffering over flavors, this suffering cannot be described.
The small mind always hopes, not knowing contentment in desires,
The suffering that is experienced, this suffering is indescribable.
The meeting of enemies and those who are not loved is like a great poisonous fire,
The suffering and distress that arises, this suffering is indescribable.
In the separation from loved ones, beings give rise to great suffering,
The great evil that is difficult to endure, this suffering is indescribable.
The great suffering and fear of cold and heat, giving rise to immeasurable kinds of suffering,
The great suffering that is extremely violent and evil, this suffering is indescribable.
The suffering of illness harms people's lives, illness is the messenger of the king of death,
Beings experience this suffering, this suffering is indescribable.
Being driven by others, always without independence,
Beings experience this suffering, this suffering is indescribable.
The poison of love burns beings, pursuing and experiencing great suffering,
In succession up to death, this suffering is indescribable.
If one associates with bad friends, suffering is constantly uninterrupted,
One will experience the suffering of the evil destinies, this suffering is indescribable.
If one's wife and children experience misfortune, seeing it gives rise to great suffering,
Exceeding the suffering of hell, this suffering is indescribable.
Hunger and thirst burn one's body, like a fierce flame,
Able to destroy body and mind, this suffering is indescribable.
One is always despised by others, by relatives and acquaintances,
Giving rise to sorrow and lamentation, this suffering is indescribable.
People are oppressed by old age, with a weak body and inferior mind,
Bent over with a cane, this suffering is indescribable.
People are seized by death, from this world to the next,
This death is great suffering, it cannot be expressed.
Beings are unable to see it, and karma cannot block it,
Able to destroy all sentient beings, therefore it is called death.
With great power, difficult to endure, able to cause all sentient beings,
To proceed alone in great fear, therefore it is called death.
Sentient beings ultimately have a time fire that cannot be avoided,
Able to cut off the life of sentient beings, therefore it is called death.
Destroyed by the king of death, able to cut off the life-force of people,
Exhausting the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, therefore it is called death.
Birth necessarily has separation, from knowledge, friends, and brothers,
Having separated, they will not meet again, therefore it is called death.
And before death arrives, one should cultivate good conduct,
Death is evil and has no compassion, before it arrives one should cultivate goodness.
This death is very sudden and violent, extremely evil and has no compassion,
Before it arrives, one is able to cultivate goodness, and is truly a god.
If wisdom arises within the Dharma, this is called a person with a good life,
If a person does not depart from the Dharma, this is called the life within the life.
